Manuscript title: Halloysite nanotubes - An efficient ‘nano-support’ for the immobilization of α-amylase
Gaurav Pandey, Diogos Marcos Munguambe, Maithri Tharmavaram, Deepak Rawtani ⁎, Y.K. Agrawal Gujarat Forensic Sciences University, Sector 18A, Near Police Bhawan, Gandhinagar, India

E-mail address: rawtanid@gmail.com (D. Rawtani).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.clay.2016.11.034 0169-1317/© 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Article history: Received 17 October 2016 Received in revised form 27 November 2016 Accepted 30 November 2016 Available online xxxx
Amylases are a class of hydrolytic enzymes which help in the conversion of starch into reduced sugars. Several solid carriers have been utilized for the immobilization of amylase. The current study focused on the utilization of halloysite nanotubes (Hal nanotubes) for the immobilization ofα-amylase post their surface functionalization with APTES. The immobilized enzymewas characterized for its ultrastructure andmorphology using TEMwhich revealed the hollow tubular structure of nanotubes. Chemical characterization of Amylase-Hal nanotubes powderwas done by FTIR inwhich the characteristic reflections of pristine Hal nanotubes and amylasewere detected in the spectra for Amylase-Hal nanotubes powder. The thermal and crystalline behavior of the immobilized enzymewas studiedusingDSC andXRDanalysis respectively. Further, the effect of time, pH, temperature andmetal ions on the enzymatic activity of immobilized enzyme had also been probed into. The optimum pH and temperature for the immobilized amylase was found to be 7.4 and 40 °C respectively. Slight increase in the enzymatic activity was also found for immobilized amylase as compared to free enzyme in the presence of Cu2+ and Mn2+ ions.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Enzymes are biocatalysts that are highly competent and specific under diverse environments because of which, they have numerous industrial applications. The enzymes used for such applications are expected to aid in several prospects like efficient consumption of reactants, improvement of the operational time and the maximization of velocity of catalysis (Panzavolta et al., 2005; Kahraman et al., 2007; Tripathi et al., 2007; Sahoo et al., 2011). Limitations associated with the usage of enzymes in industries include low stability, high selectivity towards the process conditions and high cost (Krajewska, 2004; Cao, 2005; Hernandez and Fernandez-Lafuente, 2011). During the last two decades, several advancements have been done in the field of enzyme technology which assist their usage for numerous industrial applications (Veesar et al., 2015). Nelson andGriffin in 1916 discovered that invertase on absorption onto charcoal hydrolyses sucrose (Nelson and Griffin, 1916). Since then immobilization of enzymes on a solid support has gained considerable attention. Immobilization is a technique in which insoluble bio-catalytic derivatives are prepared through coupling of enzymes to organic or inorganic solid supports. Some of the advantages of immobilization of enzymes include enhanced stability towards organic solvents and hostile reaction conditions, repetitive usage, easy
evelopment, Gujarat Forensic dhinagar 382007, Gujarat, India.
separation from the reaction mixture, formulation of product in a controlled manner and high thermal stability (Monsan and Combes, 1988; Mateo and Torres, 2003). Organic support materials lack several properties that the inorganic materials benefit from. Some of the properties include resistibility againstmicrobial attacks and organic solvents, stability and ease of reusability or disposal (Rawtani and Agrawal, 2012a).
Amylases are a class of hydrolytic enzymes which help in the conversion of starch into reduced sugars, syrups and dextrin (Pascoal et al., 2011). They act as an important biocatalyst in food, fermentation, detergent, paper and textile industries (Kirk et al., 2002; Van derMaarel et al., 2002; Gupta et al., 2003; Polaina and MacCabe, 2007). The enzyme due to its many applications in different industries provokes the need to be immobilized in order to favor the improvement of stability and reusability of enzymes like many others (Zhongjie et al., 2013) Several physical and chemical methods are used to immobilize amylase. In chemical method, a formation of covalent or ionic bond between the support and the enzyme occurs, while in physical immobilization techniques, enzymes are either adsorbed or encapsulated on or inside a solid support (Diez et al., 1996; Gancarz et al., 2006; Chen et al., 2009; Sen et al., 2011; Herr et al., 2013). Solid carriers used for the immobilization of enzyme for industrial applications should have porosity, suitable hardness and density (Zhongjie et al., 2013). Glass beads (Kahraman et al., 2007), Zirconium dioxide (Reshmi et al., 2007), metal ceramic powder (Zhongjie et al., 2013), porous molecular sieves (Yiu et al., 2001) and alumina (Reshmi et al., 2006) are someof the solid carriers incorporated
for immobilization of amylase. Clay minerals can also be used as an effective solid support for the immobilization of enzyme (Rahman et al., 2005).
Clay is formed through the combination of one ormore clayminerals with traces of metal oxides and organic matter. Clay minerals such as kaolinite and montmorillonite are generally formed through the gradual chemical weathering of rocks over a long period of time. Claymineral consists of layers that are negatively charged, with hydrated cations placed in the interlayer spaces balancing the negative charge (Murray, 1991, 2000; Joseph et al., 2013). Hal is one such clay mineral that is chemically an aluminosilicate and is similar to kaolin which has the same chemical formula as Al2Si2O5(OH)4 (Levis and Deasy, 2002). Hal nanotubes are ultra-small hollow tubes whose diameters are generally lesser than 100 nm. The lengths normally range from about 500 nm to over 1.2 μm. Aluminum, silicon and hydrogen elements are the key constituents of these nanotubes (Rawtani and Agrawal, 2012a, 2012b). The
Fig. 2. XRD Patterns of Amylase-Hal
chemical properties of the outer surface of Hal nanotubes are similar to that of silica (SiO2), and bears a negative charge at higher pH (zeta potential) while alumina (Al2O3) constitutes the inner core and provides a positive charge at lower pH (Tari et al., 1999). Due to their large specific surface area, high biocompatibility and nanotubular structure, they are used as support materials. They have been widely used for the loading and controlled release study of various substances which range from lowmolecularmass organicmolecules to complex biochemicalmolecules (Yuan et al., 2015). Some of the lowmolecularmass compounds loaded onHal nanotubes include benzotriazole (Abdullayev and Lvov, 2010), glycerol (Suh et al., 2011), ibuprofen (Tan et al., 2013, 2014), resveratrol (Vergaro et al., 2012) and 5-fluorouracil (Rao et al., 2014). Biochemical substances like lipase (Vaidya et al., 2008), metalloporphyrins (Machado et al., 2008), urease (Zhai et al., 2010), antisense oligonucleotides (Shi et al., 2011), and insulin (Abdullayev and Lvov, 2011) have also been loaded in the Hal nanotubes. Enzymes like
nanotubes and Hal nanotubes.
lipase and urease have been used in order to check the influence of surface chemistry and pore size on the adsorption capacity of enzyme on the surface of Hal as immobilization matrices.
A disadvantage with using Hal nanotubes as a carrier for different compounds is the display of fast release behavior (Levis and Deasy, 2003) and low loading capacity (Veerabadran et al., 2007) of the loaded molecule. The reason pertaining to this behavior is the weak hydrogen bonding or Van der Waals forces between the loaded molecule and Hal nanotube causing them to have less affinity for the loadedmolecule (Aguzzi et al., 2007). Hal is suitable for organosilanemodification due to the hydroxyl groups present on its surface (Yuan et al., 2008). Thismodification does not affect its biocompatibility (Shi et al., 2011). The specific functional groups of the grafted organosilane, especially on the outer surface, cause development of a stronger interaction, such as complexation or electrostatic attraction, between the modified Hal nanotubes and the loaded molecule (Tan et al., 2013; Yuan et al., 2012).
The current work deals with the immobilization of α-amylase onto Hal nanotubes which act as a solid, inorganic support for the immobilization of the enzyme. Similar studies published previously have reported low loading capacity of the enzymes due to less affinity between the enzyme and Hal nanotubes (Zhai et al., 2010; Tully et al., 2016). This drawback can be overcome by the organosilane modification of Hal nanotubes. This paper will focus on the surface functionalization of
Hal nanotubes with 3-aminopropyl triethoxysilane (APTES) and using them for enzyme loading and release studies. A novel biochemical method based on the detection of glucose using 3, 5-dinitrosalicylic acid (DNS) method was employed to check the activity of the immobilized α-amylase. Parameters like time, pH, temperature and metal ions were varied to check their effect on the enzymatic activity of the immobilized enzyme.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicals and enzyme
sections.text:
α-amylase (1,4-α-D-glucan-glucanohydrolase) was purchased from HiMedia Laboratories. Hal nanotubes were provided by New Zealand China Clays Ltd. 3-aminopropyl triethoxysilane (APTES) was purchased fromSigmaAldrich. Other chemicals viz. 3, 5-dinitrosalicylic acid (DNS), toluene, sodium sulphite, sodium potassium tartrate, starch, calcium chloride, copper sulphate, magnesium sulphate, manganese chloride and sodium hydroxide were purchased from Finar Reagents (Ahmedabad, India). The reagents were of analytical grade and were used without any additional purification. All the aqueous preparations of the reagents were carried out in double distilled water.

sections.heading: 2.2. Functionalization of halloysite nanotubes
sections.text: Organosilane modified Hal nanotubes were prepared according to the procedure generally applied for the grafting of silica-basedmaterials (Vansant et al., 1995). 10mL of APTESwas dissolved in toluene. Approximately 3 g of clay powder (Hal nanotubes) was added, and the dispersion was ultrasonicated for 30 min. The dispersion was kept under constant stirring for 24 h at 70 °C. The resultant solid phasemixture obtained after 24 h was filtered and thoroughly washed with toluene to eliminate the excess organosilane and dried at room temperature for 48 h.

sections.heading: 2.3. Immobilization of enzyme on halloysite nanotubes
sections.text: The immobilization of α-amylase on nanotubes was carried out as follows: A 10mg/mL solution ofα-amylase was prepared in double distilled water. Functionalized Hal nanotubes was added into the enzyme solution and themixturewas continuously stirred for 24 h at room temperature. The nanotubes loaded with the enzyme were recovered by centrifugation, washed by buffer solution and stored at 4 °C for further enzymatic activity assays.

sections.heading: 2.4. Characterization studies
sections.text:
Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) of Hal nanotubes (before and after immobilization of enzyme) was performed using a 300 kV, FEI make (Tecnai G2 F30 model) transmission electron microscope. The specimens were made according to the following procedure: The clay mineral was ultrasonically dispersed in propanol for 5 min, and a small drop of the dispersion was placed on a copper grid. The grid was allowed to stand for 5 min before transferring it into the microscope. X-ray Diffractometer (D8 DISCOVER, Brukar AXS GmBH, Germany) with the CuKα radiation (λ = 1.543 Å) in the Bragg-Brentano configuration (operated at 80 kV, 80 mA) was used to characterize the
crystalline phases in Hal nanotubes and Enzyme-Hal nanotubes powder. Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR-JASCO 4100) was used to obtain the infrared vibration spectrum of enzyme, Hal nanotubes and Enzyme-Hal nanotubes powder by mixing sample with the Potassium Bromide (KBr) in 1:100 ratios and preparing the pellet in the pellet press, followed by analysis in the spectral range of 4000– 400 cm−1 with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Thermal behavior of Hal nanotubes, functionalized Hal nanotubes, enzyme and Enzyme-Hal nanotubes powder was performed by Differential Scanning Calorimetry (DSC-6000, Perkin-Elmer). Spectrophotometric analysis of the enzymatic activity was done with UV–Visible Spectrophotometer (JASCOV360).

sections.heading: 2.5. In vitro enzyme loading study
sections.text:
The percentage of enzyme loaded on nanotubes was calculated by measuring the enzymatic activity of α-amylase in initial enzyme solution and Amylase-Hal nanotubes mixture (after 24 h) using DNS method. Starch was used as the substrate to study the activity of enzyme. Aliquot of initial amylase solution was taken and added into the starch solution. After incubating for a few minutes, DNS solution was added, followed by 10 min of incubation at 90 °C. The optical density of the resulting solution wasmeasured at 575 nmpost addition of sodium potassium tartrate using UV–Visible Spectrophotometer (JASCO-V360). Similar procedurewas followed for the Amylase-Hal nanotubesmixture which was initially centrifuged at 2000 rpm, followed by the collection of aliquot of enzyme from the supernatant tomeasure the enzymatic activity. sections.heading: 2.6. Factors affecting the enzymatic activity of immobilized amylase
2.6.1. Time
sections.text: For studying the effect of time, the dried Hal nanotubes-enzyme powder was soaked in 50 mL of phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) and continuously stirred at 1100 rpm. Aliquotswere taken at regular time intervals to measure the enzymatic activity as per the procedure in Section 2.5.

sections.heading: 2.6.2. pH
sections.text:
The dried Hal nanotubes-enzyme powder was soaked in 50 ml of buffer solution with variable pH ranging from 4 to 9 and continuously

stirred at 1100 rpm at room temperature. Aliquots were taken after 1 h of stirring and enzymatic activity wasmeasured as per the procedure in Section 2.5.

sections.heading: 2.6.3. Temperature
sections.text: Dried Hal nanotubes-enzyme powder was soaked in 50 ml of buffer solution (pH 7.4) at different temperatures ranging from 30 to 70 °C. The mixture was stirred at 1100 rpm. Aliquots were taken after 1 h of stirring and enzymatic activity was measured as per the procedure in Section 2.5.

sections.heading: 2.6.4. Metal ions
sections.text: Aqueous solutions of CaCl2, CuSO4, MgSO4 and MnCl2 of variable concentration (2, 4, 6 g/L) were prepared for studying the effect of Ca2+, Cu2+, Mg2+ and Mn2+ ions. Dried Enzyme-Hal nanotubes powder was soaked in 50ml solution (pH 7.4) of eachmetal salt of different concentrations along with a control sample of Enzyme-Hal nanotubes powder which was soaked in double distilled water. The mixture was stirred at 1100 rpm. Aliquots were taken after 1 h of stirring and enzymatic activity was measured as per the procedure in Section 2.5.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization studies
sections.text:
The ultrastructural andmorphological analysis of the Hal nanotubes using TEM has been depicted in Fig. 1. The TEM images obtained clearly reveal the hollow tubular structure of Hal nanotubes with open ends (Fig. 1a). The nanotubes had an average length of 0.3–2 μm and the outer diameter ranging between 50 and 100 nm. The diameter of the lumen was between 10 and 30 nm. There was a slight increase in the outer diameter of the nanotubes post surface functionalization with APTES (Fig. 1b). The lumen of the functionalized Hal nanotube was also not clearly visible. Fig. 1c confirmed the immobilization of amylase on the Hal nanotubes. The dark spots in the image could be attributed to the enzyme immobilized on the outer surface of the Hal nanotubes. Few spots were also visible in the lumen of the nanotube. This reveals the loading of the enzyme on the outer as well as inner surface of Hal nanotubes. The organosilane modification of the surface of Hal nanotubes was responsible for the enhanced loading of the enzyme on the outer surface of nanotubes.
The XRD patterns obtained for pristine and enzyme loaded Hal nanotubes are depicted in Fig. 2. The reflections could be indexed to the hexagonally structured Al2Si2O5(OH)4. The pristine Hal nanotubes sample exhibited a (001) basal reflection at a measured diffraction angle (2θ) of 12.2° which was equivalent to a spacing (d-value) between diffracting planes of 7.54113 Å. This could be ascribed to Hal (d-value of 7 Å). The dehydrated state of Hal nanotubes was confirmed by the presence of the (020)/(110) basal reflection at 2θ of 20.45° (dvalue of 4.381217 Å) and (002) basal reflection at 2θ of 24.9° (d-value of 3.61417 Å) (Zeng et al., 2014). The characteristic reflection of quartz, themineral form of SiO2, at 2θ is 26.8° (d-value of 3.361438Å) (Liu et al., 2014). In case of Amylase-Hal nanotubes powder, the reflections were slightly weaker than the reflections obtained for pristine Hal nanotubes sample. The (001) basal reflection at 2θ of 12° (d-value of 7.16142 Å) was weaker than the pristine Hal nanotubes which might be because of the adsorption of enzyme between the layers of Hal nanotubes. Similar behavior was perceived for reflections at 2θ of 20.45° (d-value of 4.291341 Å) and 2θ of 24.9° (d-value of 3.42231 Å). Furthermore, the
characteristic reflection of quartz,whichwas present in the XRD pattern of Hal nanotubes at 2θ of 26.8° was missing in the XRD pattern of Amylase-Hal nanotubes sample. Overall, it could be deduced that a decrease in the crystallinity for pristine Hal nanotubes sample occurs upon immobilization of α-amylase in the nanotubes.
Fig. 3 reports the FTIR vibration spectrum of the α-amylase, Hal nanotubes and Amylase-Hal nanotubes sample in the spectral range of 4000–400 cm−1. A detailed information on the secondary structure of the polypeptide chain can be found in the spectra ofα-amylase through the infrared absorption bands of amide groups present in the protein. The characteristic absorption bands for α-amylase had been detected at 1654 and 1369 cm−1. For pristine Hal nanotubes sample, the characteristic absorption bandswere found at 3698, 3625, 1029 and 910 cm−1. The vibration IR spectra of Amylase-Hal nanotubes sample exhibited the characteristic absorption bands of both, the enzyme as well as the pristine Hal nanotubes sample. This demonstrated that the enzyme was immobilized in the nanotubes. The absorption band at 1515 cm−1 which appears in Amylase-Hal nanotubes sample is attributed to the carboxylate vibration (Manzano et al., 2008). The presence of acidic amino acids like aspartic acid and glutamic acid causes the enzyme to possesses carboxyl groups. These groups transfer the proton to the aminopropyl (NH3+) group of the APTES which is grafted on the surface of Hal nanotubes. Due to this proton transfer, the carboxylate is formed. Therefore, there is an electrostatic interaction between the carboxyl group of the enzyme and the aminopropyl group present on the surface functionalized Hal nanotubes used for enzyme loading. This interaction is responsible for the strong affinity between the enzyme andHal nanotube, especially on the outer surface of the Hal nanotubes. A schematic representation of the loading mechanism of amylase on Hal nanotubes is shown in Fig. 4. Table 1 displays the interpretation of all the characteristic absorption bands, along with the functional groups responsible for such vibrations (Zhai et al., 2010; Rawtani and Agrawal, 2013).
DSC thermograms for the enzyme, Hal nanotubes, functionalizedHal nanotubes and Enzyme-Hal nanotubes powder were recorded for heat
flow against the temperature (Fig. 5). The scan for heat flow (milliwatt, mW) versus temperature for pristine Hal nanotubes sample remained unchanged with no peaks throughout the scan (Rawtani et al., 2013). Upon functionalization, Hal nanotubes exhibited an endothermal, broad peak at 100–130 °Cwhich could be attributed to the organophilic nature of the Hal nanotubes. It was an evidence of the decrease in the amount of adsorbedH2O at the surface of Hal nanotubes due to the presence of organosilanes. Further, an exothermal shift at 300-350 °C in the thermogram of functionalized Hal nanotubes could be attributed to the decomposition of silane bonded with the Hal nanotubes through secondary interactions or due to grafting onto Al-OH and Si-OH groups present in nanotubes. It could also be ascribed to the decomposition of oligomerized network of silanewhich did not get removedwhile washing (Yuan et al., 2008; Carlia et al., 2014). Thermogramofα-amylase revealed a broad, endothermal band at 60–90 °C and 200–240 °C which could be because of the opening of random chains and α-helices, respectively, present in the protein leading to its denaturation at such high temperatures. Further, a sharp exothermal reflection at 260- 280 °C could be because of the transition of amorphous amylase into the crystalline form. Again, a narrow, endothermal band at 320– 350 °C could be attributed to the melting behavior of the enzyme (Sankalia et al., 2007). In case of Amylase-Hal nanotubes, a shift in the endothermal broad band occurred at 100–120 °Cwhile in pristine amylase sample it had not. This could be attributed to the increase in the denaturation temperature for the enzyme upon immobilization.
Further, the exothermal shift at 300–350 °C observed in the thermogram of functionalized Hal nanotubes was not observed in case of Amylase- Hal nanotubes. The thermogram remained stable throughout the scan. This thermal stability in the Amylase-Hal nanotubes sample could be because of the strong electrostatic interaction between the enzyme and the functionalizedHal nanotubes. The strong affinity between the carboxyl groups of the enzyme and the aminopropyl groups of the functionalized Hal nanotubes resulted in increased thermal stability of the organosilane network of the Hal nanotubes. This also confirms the immobilization of enzyme on the surface of functionalized Hal nanotubes. No peaks were present for crystallization of enzyme by which, it could be deduced that the enzyme maintained its amorphous nature upon immobilization.

sections.heading: 3.2. Enzyme loading study
sections.text: The enzymatic activity measurement was performed as per the procedure mentioned in Section 2.5 before and after loading of α-amylase on Hal nanotubes. The formula used for calculating the percentage of enzyme loaded on Hal nanotubes has already been mentioned in Section 2.5. Table 2 presents the optical density of the samples along with the percentage of enzyme loaded on Hal nanotubes.

sections.heading: 3.3. Factors affecting the enzymatic activity of immobilized amylase
3.3.1. Time
sections.text: The effect of time on the enzymatic activity of α-amylase upon immobilization in Hal nanotubes has been presented in Fig. 6. An immediate increase in the enzymatic activity was spotted after first 2 h which might be due to the immediate release of the loosely bound enzyme on the surface of nanotubes. With time, the enzymatic activity of amylase became constant which could be ascribed to immobilization of enzyme in the nanotubes.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. pH
sections.text: The effect of pH on the enzymatic activity ofα-amylase upon immobilization in Hal nanotubes has been illustrated in Fig. 7. There was a gradual decrease in the enzymatic activity of immobilized amylase in acidic as well as alkaline conditions. The decrease in the activity of enzyme could be attributed to the change in protonation patternwhich ultimately causes the enzyme to denature. The literature (Dutta et al., 2006) suggested the optimum pH for the activity of free amylase to be 6.5. From the study, the maximum enzymatic activity for the immobilized enzyme was reported at pH 7.4 which was higher than the optimum pH for the free amylase. Thus, immobilized amylase showed increased resistance towards the pH change when compared to the free enzyme.

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Temperature
sections.text: The effect of temperature on the enzymatic activity of α-amylase upon immobilization in Hal nanotubes has been demonstrated in Fig. 8. Therewas a gradual decrease in the enzymatic activity of immobilized amylase upon increasing the temperature. The decrease in the activity of enzyme could be attributed to the breakage of weaker hydrogen and ionic bonds within the enzyme, leading to change in shape of the active sites and ultimately triggering the denaturation of the enzyme. The literature work (Dutta et al., 2006) reported the optimum temperature of free amylase enzyme to be 30 °C. From the study,maximumenzymatic activity for immobilized enzyme was noticed at 40 °C. So, it could be deduced that the immobilized enzyme showed increased thermal stability as compared to the free enzyme.

sections.heading: 3.3.4. Metal ions
sections.text:
The effect of metal ions (Ca2+, Mg2+, Cu2+ andMn2+) on the enzymatic activity of α-amylase upon immobilization in Hal nanotubes has been presented in Fig. 9. α-Amylase is not known to have an obligate necessity of metal ions to be active. But, the free enzyme exhibited no activity in the presence of Co2+, Cu2+, Mn2+ and Ba2+ which could be because of the competition among the protein-linked cation and the exogenous cation (de Carvalho et al., 2008). No significant effect was detected on the enzymatic activity of the immobilized enzyme in the presence of Ca2+ ion while in the presence of Mg2+ ion, a slight inactivation of the enzyme happened with increase in the concentration
of the ion. The immobilized amylase was able to exhibit a slight enzymatic activity in the presence of Cu2+ and Mn2+ ions which depicted the increased tolerance of amylase towards metal ions upon immobilization in the nanotubes.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
Hal nanotubes had been used as an inorganic, solid support for the immobilization of α-amylase, a hydrolytic biocatalyst having wide range of industrial applications. The nanotubeswere initially functionalized with APTES in order to modify the surface of nanotubes with organosilanes. The immobilization of enzyme was performed at room temperature in double distilled water. It has been found that 69.23% of the enzyme was loaded on the nanotubes.
TEM analysis of the Amylase-Hal nanotubes revealed the immobilization of enzyme majorly on the outer surface of nanotubes. FTIR data confirmed the loading of amylase on Hal nanotubes due to the presence of characteristic reflections of both, amylase as well as Hal nanotubes in the spectra obtained for Amylase-Hal nanotubes powder. XRD analysis presented a decrease in the crystallinity of Hal nanotubes upon immobilization of amorphous enzyme. This was further confirmed by the thermogram obtained through DSC analysis in which no reflection for crystallization was present. Apart from a broad, endothermal band, the thermogram remained unaltered throughout the scan for the Amylase-Hal nanotubes sample.
The maximum enzymatic activity of the immobilized amylase was noticed at an optimum pH of 7.4 and at an optimum temperature of 40 °C which were higher than those for free enzyme. The immobilized enzyme also exhibited slight activity in the presence of Cu2+ and Mn2+ ions whichwas higher when compared to no activity for free enzyme in presence of such ions.
It can be concluded that this work helps to overcome the limitations of reduced catalytic activity of amylase associated with changes in pH and temperature. In future, this research work can be helpful in various industries like textile, paper and pulp, detergent, food and fermentation to prepare a cost-effective Nano-support of Hal nanotubes with immobilized amylase to enhance the reusability of the enzyme.

metadata.abstractText: Article history: Received 17 October 2016 Received in revised form 27 November 2016 Accepted 30 November 2016 Available online xxxx Amylases are a class of hydrolytic enzymes which help in the conversion of starch into reduced sugars. Several solid carriers have been utilized for the immobilization of amylase. The current study focused on the utilization of halloysite nanotubes (Hal nanotubes) for the immobilization ofα-amylase post their surface functionalization with APTES. The immobilized enzymewas characterized for its ultrastructure andmorphology using TEMwhich revealed the hollow tubular structure of nanotubes. Chemical characterization of Amylase-Hal nanotubes powderwas done by FTIR inwhich the characteristic reflections of pristine Hal nanotubes and amylasewere detected in the spectra for Amylase-Hal nanotubes powder. The thermal and crystalline behavior of the immobilized enzymewas studiedusingDSC andXRDanalysis respectively. Further, the effect of time, pH, temperature andmetal ions on the enzymatic activity of immobilized enzyme had also been probed into. The optimum pH and temperature for the immobilized amylase was found to be 7.4 and 40 °C respectively. Slight increase in the enzymatic activity was also found for immobilized amylase as compared to free enzyme in the presence of Cu and Mn ions. © 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
